intro: Voyria corymbosa, commonly known as the clustered voyria, is a flowering plant native to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its dense, compact growth habit. The plant produces showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are evergreen, leathery, and dark green, providing year-round interest in the landscape. Voyria corymbosa thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
